docs.text: Welcome to MkDocs For full documentation visit mkdocs.org . Commands mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project. mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server. mkdocs build - Build the documentation site. mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit. Project layout mkdocs.yml # The configuration file. docs/ index.md # The documentation homepage. ... # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.text: Exercise: Add and Analyze a Process Introduction How to Complete the Exercise in this Tutorial This tutorial will teach you how to use Process HQ to add a new business process, identify process inefficiencies, create a process view, and create a custom KPI. Follow the steps in Exercise 1 to access Appian Community Edition, and then deploy the Order Management (OM) application from the app catalog. How Can I Practice? You should practice in Appian Community Edition. This free, community Appian resource comes with the ability to deploy pre-built Appian applications. Keep in mind that this is a community environment not suitable for production workloads or sensitive information. Appian Version Appian Community Edition is on the latest Appian version. If you are following the exercises from a previous Appian version, go to academy.appian.com to download the latest version. Naming Conventions When you register for Appian Community Edition, you gain access to a workspace, which is your personal area within the community environment. When your workspace has been assigned, you will receive a confirmation email with a workspace ID. Pre-loaded apps in your workspace include the workspace ID. Use this workspace ID when creating new applications and objects. Otherwise, you could run into naming conflicts with objects created by other users. In the example below, the application prefix for the Acme Auto Solution app is W0000AS. So, the workspace ID is W0000, which would be included in any new app's prefix. App Catalog The App Catalog contains the most recent versions of pre-built apps available in Appian Community Edition. To go to the App Catalog, on Community Edition Home, click BROWSE APP CATALOG . To determine if you have the latest app version, select the app in the list and review the last updated date. If this date is later than when you registered for Appian Community Edition, you should deploy a new version. If you recently received your workspace, you likely have the latest versions. Save Often Appian does not automatically save updates, so save your objects frequently. Additional Resources Appian provides a number of training resources for Appian developers. The following resources are particularly popular with our learners: Academy Online - Appian's online courses provide useful survey courses, step-by-step tutorials, and practice exercises. Explore these resources at your own pace. Survey courses will help you develop a better grasp of the topics you need to learn. Video and print tutorials will help you with getting hands-on experience with Appian. Community Discussions for New Users - Check out the New to Appian thread in Community. Join our community of experts to ask questions and find answers from past discussions. Appian Documentation - Appian's product documentation will provide you with an overview of key Appian features, newest release information, additional tutorials, and helpful patterns and recipes to implement in your app. Exercise 1: Access Appian Community Edition The exercises are developed for Appian Community Edition. Once you register, you will have access to your own Appian workspace. The workspace comes with preloaded objects that you will need as you complete these steps. Follow the steps below to register: Go to Appian Community Edition . Sign in with your Appian Community credentials. Select a region, then complete the onboarding questions and acknowledgement. When your workspace has been assigned, you’ll receive a confirmation email. Keep in mind that this is a community environment not suitable for production workloads or sensitive information. For help accessing this environment, please email CommunityEdition@appian.com . To get the pre-built app used in these exercises, follow the steps below: From Community Edition Home, click BROWSE APP CATALOG . Select the Order Management, Click DEPLOY APP TO WORKSPACE then DEPLOY to deploy the application. The deployment may take several minutes. When complete, you’ll receive a confirmation email, and the new app will appear in your workspace. Exercise 2: Add a Process in Process Insights Role: Data Steward Scenario Next Gen wants to investigate their order fulfillment process to identify the cause of a recent increase in the average order fulfillment duration. To enable this analysis, you — a data steward with the permission for handling the order-related record types in Process HQ — will set up a process in the Process Insights page. First, you’ll identify the correct record types and will use them to add a process to the Process Insights page. Then you’ll configure process security to make this process available for analysis by qualified business analysts. Log into Appian Community Edition and access Process HQ from the navigation menu. Click to open the Process Insights page. Click the + ADD PROCESS button in the right-hand corner. Select the Order Submissions record type, and click NEXT . Select the Order Submission Events record type, and click NEXT . Next, Appian allows you to select or deselect the fields from the case and event history record types based on what attributes you want to make available to analysts in Process HQ. You can also create custom attributes to refine your existing data. In this exercise, you’ll group order prices into three buckets: low, medium, and high. In the Configure Case Data step, click ADD CUSTOM ATTRIBUTE. In the Create Custom Attribute dialog, select Groups Based on a Range , and click NEXT . Apply the following configurations: In the Create Groups From field, select Price . In the Number of Groups field, click the + icon to add a third group. In the Custom Attribute Value fields, enter the following values: Low includes values ≤ 2000. Medium includes values >2000 and ≤ 6000. High includes any remaining values. Click TEST to preview the values, then NEXT . Enter attribute properties: Name : Enter Price Group . Description : Enter Low: Price ≤ 2000, Medium: 2000 < Price ≤ 6000, High: 6000 < Price . Click CREATE . Deselect the Price field, then click NEXT . The Price field is replaced by the Price Group attribute you just created. In the Configure Event Data step, deselect the following fields: Id from the Order Submission Events record type Event Type Id from the Order Submission Events record type Id from the Order Submission Event Type record type These fields are not useful to the analyst and do not need to be included in the process. Click MAP ATTRIBUTES . Review what each field is mapped to, and then update field mapping as follows: End Time field: Select End . The Map Attributes screen is also where you can rename attributes. This may be necessary if you have attributes from different record types that have conflicting names. Click OK, then NEXT . Configure process properties and security: Name : Enter Order Submissions (First Name Last Name) . In order to avoid naming conflicts with other users in Appian Community Edition, append your first and last name to the name of the process. Description : Enter A process for the fulfillment of submitted orders . Process Security : Verify that your user is the analyst for the process. You can click Add Users or Groups to add additional analysts or viewers for this process. Update Options : Leave the default settings. These settings control when Process HQ will check for new data in the associated record types and reevaluate process metrics. Click ADD PROCESS . Tip You’re done with adding a new process to the Process Insights page. It may take a few minutes to complete the process creation before it becomes available for analysis. Click the refresh button to see the updated status. **Congratulations! ** You just set up a process in process insights, and made it available for analysis. Exercise 3: Investigate a Process Role: Business Analyst >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image14.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Scenario In this exercise, you’ll act as a business analyst and start an investigation of the order fulfillment process. You’ll start your exploration by starting a new investigation . Appian will assist by suggesting the attributes to investigate further. Once you identify an area for improvement, you’ll create an insight to share across your team. Then, you will apply filters to create a view into a meaningful segment of your data. Finally, you’ll create a KPI for tracking a specific process metric. Explore the Process Navigate to the Process Insights page in Process HQ, and open the process you just created. \ >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image15.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Spend a few minutes on the SUMMARY tab reviewing the high-level generated discoveries, so that you can understand your process better before you dig deeper. As a business analyst, here you can accomplish the following: Review the default KPIs. Review the process diagram to see how the process runs in practice. Review the available case attributes. Review the default chart that reflects the change in volume and duration over time. Adjust the timeframe for displayed data. Try to answer the following questions? Look at the process diagram. Which activities, if any, appear to be slowing down the process? Which sequence in the process takes the longest? Look at the chart at the bottom of the SUMMARY tab. What happens to case duration as the number of cases increases? Start an Investigation An investigation is a guided experience that allows business analysts to uncover what attributes or sequences contribute the most to a specific performance issue (for example, a longer case duration). In the top right corner, click START INVESTIGATION . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image16.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Note that Appian identified that cases with the shipping vendor Pioneer Solutions are slower than average with a potential savings of over 2,000 days. The potential savings in the number of days of work you can save each year as a result of bringing the cases with this attribute in line with the average case duration of your process. \ Click Pioneer Solutions to investigate further. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image17.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Review the metrics for cases involving Pioneer Solutions. Since these cases are slower, you’ll save this as your first finding to your insight. Saving an insight will enable you to share it with other collaborators. Click + ADD TO INSIGHT . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image18.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Continue investigating by clicking **Investigate Sequences. \ ** >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image19.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Notice that the first suggested sequence to investigate Notified the Shipping Vendor → Notified the Shipping Vendor is slower than average and is a repetition. Repetitions are flagged by Process HQ since they typically indicate an inefficiency. Click Notified the Shipping Vendor → Notified the Shipping Vendor to explore the impact of this sequence on the process. \ >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image20.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Click + ADD TO INSIGHT . \ >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image21.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Click Save New Insight . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image22.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> In the next dialog, add the following for your insight: Insight Name : Enter Orders Shipped with Pioneer Solutions . Investigation Name : Enter Recent Spike in Order Fulfillment Duration . Comment (Optional) : Enter any comment to share with your team. Click SAVE AND EXIT . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image23.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Best Practice A typical insight should have 2 to 3 findings, but this number will vary based on your dataset. Include as many findings as you need to provide the right level of detail for your use case. In this exercise, you added two findings. However, a business analyst could continue with the investigation by looking at additional attributes in the process. **Congratulations! ** **You just saved an investigation with a new and valuable insight. You or other analysts can add more insights to this investigation later. ** Create a View The investigation in the previous step revealed a bottleneck involving repeated work with the shipping vendor Pioneer Solutions. Following this investigation, analysts were able to look deeper into affected processes and determine that errors in manual data entry are causing the delays. With this issue addressed, you will now create a view for your process. Views show metrics for a filtered subset of your process data. In this case, you’ll create a view that allows you to monitor cases involving Pioneer Solutions to assess performance in the future. Navigate to the SUMMARY tab. If the SUMMARY tab is not visible, you may need to navigate back to your process using the breadcrumbs at the top of the page. Open the ALL CASES dropdown and click CREATE VIEW . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image24.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> In the CREATE VIEW dialog, the default Start from Scratch option is pre-selected for you. Click NEXT . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image25.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> In the Filter by Attribute step, open Shipping Vendor and select Pioneer Solutions . Then, click NEXT . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image26.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> In the Filter by Activity step, don’t apply any filters, and click NEXT . Name your view Orders Shipped via Pioneer Solutions , and click CREATE . Once you click CREATE , the new view becomes available to all analysts for this process. Review the default KPIs that got updated to reflect your new segment of data. **Congratulations! ** **You just created a view to zoom in on a meaningful segment of your data. ** Create a KPI As you create views and conduct investigations, Appian provides you with default KPIs. However, there will be times when you want to create custom KPIs that reflect your own understanding of a business process. In this exercise, you’ll build a custom KPI to monitor the duration of the Notified the Shipping Vendor Activity and add it to the view created in the previous step. Tracking this KPI over time allows you to see at a glance if the issue at Pioneer Solutions is being appropriately addressed. Verify that you are in the view you just created: Orders Shipped via Pioneer Solutions . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image27.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Click the CUSTOM KPIS tab. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image28.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Click CREATE NEW KPI . Click Duration then NEXT . In the Create KPI dialog, select Activity Duration , and then apply the following configurations: Activity: Select Notified the Shipping Vendor . Aggregation: Select Average . Unit: Select Detect automatically . You’ll see the preview of your KPI on the right: >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image29.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Click NEXT , then configure the properties for this KPI as follows: Name : Enter Duration of Shipper Notification . Descriptions : Enter KPI to monitor the duration of the shipper notification step . Views : Select Orders Shipped via Pioneer Solutions to display the KPI in your view of the process. Click CREATE . Your KPI now displays in the CUSTOM KPIs tab. You can click the three-dot menu , and then select Pin to Summary to display this KPI together with default generated KPIs in the Summary tab. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image30.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Congratulations! You’ve created your first custom KPI. Note Custom KPIs can be added to and removed from views on the Custom KPIs tab for each view. The KPI will always reflect the data filtered for the current view. Resources Appian Product Documentation - The Appian docs page contains information on all Process HQ features and functionality. Academy Online - Visit Academy Online to enroll in all Process HQ courses. gd2md-html: xyzzy Fri Jul 26 2024
docs.title: Process Insights Tutorial
Exercise: Add and Analyze a Process

docs.text: This tutorial will teach you how to use Process HQ to add a new business process, identify process inefficiencies, create a process view, and create a custom KPI. Follow the steps in Exercise 1 to access Appian Community Edition, and then deploy the Order Management (OM) application from the app catalog.

docs.title: Exercise 1: Access Appian Community Edition
Exercise 2: Add a Process in Process Insights

To enable this analysis, you — a data steward with the permission for handling the order-related record types in Process HQ — will set up a process in the Process Insights page. docs.title: Create a View

docs.text: As you create views and conduct investigations, Appian provides you with default KPIs. However, there will be times when you want to create custom KPIs that reflect your own understanding of a business process. In this exercise, you’ll build a custom KPI to monitor the duration of the Notified the Shipping Vendor Activity and add it to the view created in the previous step. Tracking this KPI over time allows you to see at a glance if the issue at Pioneer Solutions is being appropriately addressed. Verify that you are in the view you just created: Orders Shipped via Pioneer Solutions . >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image27.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Click the CUSTOM KPIS tab. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image28.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Click CREATE NEW KPI . Click Duration then NEXT . In the Create KPI dialog, select Activity Duration , and then apply the following configurations: Activity: Select Notified the Shipping Vendor . Aggregation: Select Average . Unit: Select Detect automatically . You’ll see the preview of your KPI on the right: >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image29.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Click NEXT , then configure the properties for this KPI as follows: Name : Enter Duration of Shipper Notification . Descriptions : Enter KPI to monitor the duration of the shipper notification step . Views : Select Orders Shipped via Pioneer Solutions to display the KPI in your view of the process. Click CREATE . Your KPI now displays in the CUSTOM KPIs tab. You can click the three-dot menu , and then select Pin to Summary to display this KPI together with default generated KPIs in the Summary tab. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link here (to images/image30.png). Store image on your image server and adjust path/filename/extension if necessary. ( Back to top )( Next alert ) >>>>> Congratulations! You’ve created your first custom KPI. Note Custom KPIs can be added to and removed from views on the Custom KPIs tab for each view. The KPI will always reflect the data filtered for the current view.
docs.title: Create a KPI
